title: Wisdom and Righteous Living
shortSummary: Proverbs 13 offers practical wisdom contrasting the behaviors and outcomes of the wise and the foolish. It emphasizes the blessings of obedience, diligence, and righteousness, while warning against pride, laziness, and wickedness. This chapter encourages believers to pursue godly living through heeding instruction and valuing the fear of the Lord.

keyCharacters.name: Wise Son
keyCharacters.description: Represents those who listen to and obey their father's instruction, symbolizing the receptive and obedient believer.

keyCharacters.name: Scorner
keyCharacters.description: A person who rejects correction and instruction, embodying the foolish and rebellious individual.

keyCharacters.name: Righteous Man
keyCharacters.description: One who lives according to God's standards, characterized by integrity and moral uprightness.

keyCharacters.name: Wicked Man
keyCharacters.description: One who lives in opposition to God's ways, marked by deceit, pride, and eventual shame.

definitions.definition: One who mocks or rejects correction and instruction, showing contempt for wisdom.
A lazy person who lacks diligence and therefore experiences lack and want.
The price paid to deliver or save a life; here it refers to wealth used to preserve one's life.
To discipline or correct, often with the implication of love and care for improvement.

outline.heading: The Value of Instruction and Speech
outline.description: This section contrasts the wise who accept instruction and guard their speech with the foolish who reject correction and speak recklessly, highlighting the life-preserving power of wisdom.

outline.heading: Diligence, Righteousness, and Wealth
outline.description: These verses emphasize the blessings that come from diligence and righteousness, warning against laziness, pride, and ill-gotten wealth which ultimately lead to loss and shame.

outline.heading: Hope, Fear of the Lord, and Wisdom
outline.description: This section teaches the importance of hope fulfilled, reverence for God's commandments, and the company one keeps, showing how these influence wisdom and life outcomes.

outline.heading: Discipline, Inheritance, and Provision
outline.description: The final verses stress the necessity of accepting discipline, the blessings of leaving a godly inheritance, and the satisfaction found in righteous living versus the want of the wicked.

application: Heed parental and godly instruction promptly to cultivate wisdom and avoid destruction.
Guard your speech carefully, recognizing that words have the power to bring life or ruin.
Pursue diligence and integrity in your work, trusting God to bless your labor.
Accept loving discipline as a sign of God's care and a path to honor and growth.

keyVerses.text: A wise son heareth his father's instruction: but a scorner heareth not rebuke.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the fundamental principle that wisdom begins with a teachable and obedient heart.

keyVerses.text: He that keepeth his mouth keepeth his life: but he that openeth wide his lips shall have destruction.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the critical importance of controlling one’s speech as a means of preserving life and avoiding ruin.

keyVerses.text: Wealth gotten by vanity shall be diminished: but he that gathereth by labour shall increase.
keyVerses.significance: This verse teaches the value of honest, diligent work over dishonest or quick gains that do not last.

keyVerses.text: He that spareth his rod hateth his son: but he that loveth him chasteneth him betimes.
keyVerses.significance: It affirms the biblical principle that loving discipline is essential for a child’s proper growth and moral development.
